body: IT took Ali Newman and Desmond Curran two tries to sell their two-bedroom one-bath co-op in Kensington, Brooklyn. The first try was in February 2007. They listed the apartment at $335,000 -- they had paid $190,000 for it in 2005 -- and one month later accepted an offer of $330,000. But the deal fell apart. Very shortly after that, Ms. Newman
title: THE SELL; Ax the Drapes; Move the Stuff

body: BROOKLYN CO-OP $395,000 BROOKLYN: 30 Ocean Parkway, #1L (between East Seventh Street and Sherman Street), Windsor Terrace One block from Prospect Park, a one-bedroom one-bath ground-floor apartment with a large foyer and an eat-in kitchen in an Art Deco building with a common garden. Robert T. Frye, Prudential Douglas Elliman, (917) 586-7923;

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began. The ''time on the market'' is from the most recent listing to the sales agreement. author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: West Side Rail Hopes Q. Millions are being spent on the East Side Access project, bringing some Long Island Rail Road trains into Grand Central. So why no ''West Side Access,'' which would let Metro-North trains go into Pennsylvania Station? A. ''No room at the inn,'' said Marjorie Anders, a Metro-North spokeswoman. Penn Station is full, she said,
title: F. Y. I.

body: WINDSOR TERRACE COTTAGE $825,000 BROOKLYN: 127 Vanderbilt Street (near McDonald Avenue) An early 1900s frame house with two bedrooms, two baths and a separate shed with electricity. Marie Parker, Brooklyn Properties (718) 857-2525; www.brooklynproperties.com Open house Sunday, 1 to 3 p.m. TAXES: $1,550 a year PROS: Charming and recently upgraded,
title: ON THE MARKET

body: THESE days, when you find a chef with the urge to tinker, he will most likely be embroiled in such delicate work as teasing out the covalent bonds of mayonnaise or synthesizing panko gelatin. But what about the rougher breeds of food geek, those who, if not for a culinary passion, would have wound up in their yard, building rockets out of scrap
title: Pizza From Scratch: First, Get Bricks and a Trailer

body: ZOMBIECON There are still two weeks until Halloween, and already the undead are out in force. ZombieCon, the annual parade of the bloody, the battered and the strangely animated, takes place on Saturday. For the fourth year participants in this loosely organized spectacle will roam the streets of Manhattan (above), dressed in their best
title: Spare Times

body: UNTIL early last month, Debra Fierro drove each day from her home in Charleston, near the southern tip of Staten Island, and parked her white S.U.V. in front of Rubyfruit Bar and Grill, the Hudson Street tavern that she opened in 1994. Ms. Fierro, 53, dressed in running clothes, usually arrived around noon and took inventory for that night's
title: Bailout at the Local Bar

body: FOR some would-be home sellers, the big question isn't whether they should sell, but where they should move. In the summer of 2007, Davida and Bret Hogan were in just such a quandary. With a new baby, the possibility of more space had taken on new appeal. They decided to go house hunting to see what might tempt them away from their two-bedroom
title: THE SELL; It Pays to Be Prepared, and Patient

author: E-mail: susan.dominus @nytimes.com
body: Andrew Berends, a documentary filmmaker who lives in Brooklyn, only had the chance to make a phone call about 15 hours after he was detained by Nigerian officials while gathering footage of women at a market in the Niger Delta, an area rich with oil and with frequent militant uprisings. The moment he could, he called a friend in Nigeria and
title: BIG CITY; Detained in Nigeria, A Lifeline in New York

body: Crumpled Towers And E. B. White To the Editor: ''Reflections on That Tuesday'' (Sept. 7), Ed Park's essay of rumination about the seventh anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, quoted an observation by W. G. Sebald, in his novel ''Austerlitz,'' that ''somehow we know by instinct that outsize buildings cast the shadow of their own destruction
title: LETTERS; In 1948, a Warning About Tall Buildings

body: To the Editor: Imagine my surprise and dismay upon returning from nearly three months abroad to read about the closing of Le Figaro Cafe (''Blowin' in the Forgotten Wind,'' Dispatches, Aug. 24). My late husband and I met there for the first time in the summer of 1967, and the life of the cafe always seemed to reflect what has happening in the city
title: When The Figaro Dies, It's a Sign of the Times

body: If no good deed is allowed to go unpunished, Kathryn Martinez should have seen two punishments coming. To reduce their reliance on commercial food sources, she and her fianc√© planted a vegetable garden in the backyard of their home in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. Hesitant to pick their lettuce too soon, they left it in the ground. When they finally
title: Bumps on the Road to a Greener City

body: When he was 5 years old, Billy O'Connor stood on a Brooklyn street with his mother and two sisters, and for the last time, watched his father fight a fire. It was August 2, 1978. The O'Connors were supposed to go the beach that day, but when they went to the firehouse that morning to pick up Billy's father, Firefighter William O'Connor, at the end
title: A Memory They Refuse To Let Fade

body: Late one night, shortly after Kai Lui and his wife, Laura Campbell-Lui, moved into their Queen Anne-style house in Midwood, Brooklyn, she shook him awake, insisting that she heard intruders. Mr. Lui went to investigate and discovered noises coming from the fourth-floor attic. He called the police. ''They had their weapons drawn,'' said Mr. Lui, a
title: The City's Latest Real Estate Fight: Humans Against Raccoons

body: THE developer of the Classic, a condominium conversion in a former scale factory in Kew Gardens, Queens, wanted a quiet residential area for their six-story brick-and-stucco building. And he got it, in an area packed with aging colonials and prewar co-ops. The developer, Jackie Kamali, a principal of the Kamali Organization, based in Great Neck,
title: POSTING; Whistling Past the Condominiums

body: To the Editor: It was with great interest and nostalgia that I read ''Tree Proud'' and ''Let Them Count the Ways'' (June 1), the articles about New Yorkers' favorite trees. These articles brought back fond memories of my years as a teacher at Public School 9 on the Upper West Side, and more specifically to 1984 and a classroom that my fifth graders
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Maligned Buses, Beloved Trees, Perilous Crossings | What A Difference a Tree Makes!

body: In the New York Police Department, officers who reach the rank of sergeant typically retire after 20 to 25 years on the force. Sgt. Andrew P. McGoey waited longer to turn in his badge -- a lot longer. On Monday at police headquarters in Lower Manhattan, Sergeant McGoey will surrender Shield No. 801 after 39 years on the force. Of the city's roughly
title: After 39 Years, a Police Sergeant Retires Only Because He Must

body: An article in some editions on May 17 about the killing of Kyung-Sook Woo, the owner of a dry-cleaning shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, included an erroneous age from the police for the victim. She was 62, not 52. The error was repeated on May 19 in an article in some editions about an arrest in the case.
title: Corrections: For the Record

body: An article in some editions on May 17 about the killing of Kyung-Sook Woo, the owner of a dry-cleaning shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, referrred incorrectly to the length of her hair, which friends said she often did not curl until she was at work because she had risen so early to open the shop. Her hair was short, not long.
title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD

body: FOR Maggie Tobin and Bob Mason, the last straw in Park Slope was the parking. The couple, who have two young children, lived there for eight years and loved being near Prospect Park and surrounded by friends. But when the time came to buy, they wanted more space and found the prices too high, and they decided they could also live without the ritual
title: LIVING IN KENSINGTON, BROOKLYN; Name From London, People From Everywhere

body: Eden Dry Cleaners and Tailoring opened about 8:30 a.m. on Saturday. Kenneth Oh and a friend assisted the first customers. His younger brother, Daniel Oh, and some helpers arrived a few hours later. Bouquets of flowers were pushed up against the window ledges, and there was still the thinnest of threads running through their mother's sewing machine.
title: Dry Cleaner Reopens With Tears For Owner

body: A 22-year-old man was arrested Sunday and charged with killing a shopkeeper who was found dead in her dry cleaning store in Brooklyn last week, the police said. The suspect, Jamal Winter, was arrested at his home in Park Slope, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning. He was charged with murder and robbery, the police said. The killing shook up the
title: Arrest in Slaying Of Shopkeeper

body: When her husband became too sick five years ago to tend to the family dry-cleaning business, Kyung-Sook Woo did not hesitate to take over the job, sometimes rising so early to open the shop that customers would find her with a curling iron in her hand and her long hair half-curled. They knew Mrs. Woo, 52, as their determined but lovable dry
title: Brooklyn Dry Cleaner Is Found Dead in Her Windsor Terrace Store

body: WHEN Stefan Merrill Block was a teenager, he spent most of his time with his mother, being home-schooled near Dallas. Now he's a 26-year-old first-time author of a recently published novel, ''The Story of Forgetting'' (Random House, $25), living in a two-bedroom floor-through in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. But he still calls his mom in Texas every
title: HABITATS | WINDSOR TERRACE, BROOKLYN; Where 'Yin and Yang' Converge and Create

body: Last September, a man who has admittedly lived a hard-knock life walked into Christie's auction house with an Andy Warhol painting of a dollar sign and asked to have it put up for sale. Though one can never judge by appearances, especially when it comes to art lovers, something about this particular art lover, Jason Beltrez, seemed a little bit off
title: A Warhol Surfaces and Is Headed for Court
